section.hand:
To m
r
Secret. Au
g
9. 89

page.lettertext:
Belgia 1589 9 Au
g
To M
r
Secretary
It may please yo
r
H. upon
e Rxt of
e l
re
of
e 28 July w
ch
I Rxd by this
post
e 8 of
is p
nt
, I have bin instant agayn w
th
e
gen
r
all states
, for
a speedy answer to hir
Ma
ty
about
e matt
r
of comission
t
should be sent
to
eir Deputyes, wher upon
ey have
mysed now to take some p
nt
resolution
w
ch
as far as I
ceave wilbe redy to be sent w
th
in 3 or 4 daies, what is
like to be resolved I cannot learne by any meanes for nothing ys im
ted
w
th
e
Counsell of State
but [all] ys kept w
th
such a Jalouse secresy, as yf
they feared to be wrought by
e counsell to hold bett
r
correspondence betwene
hir Ma
ty
and
e Countrey, wh
r
in yf
t
be their meaning they shall not
find them selves deceaved, for divers lately of
e Counsell, not w
th
me
onely & in p
r
vat conference, but truely publickly & more then ever before
have complayned very bitterly against
Barnevelts
cowrses. & still
ey tell
me privately that for fear of
turbing
e state, they must forbeare to oppose
th
e
selves directly against him as also for
t
w
ch
yo
r
H. doth signifye
[becaus] they sue him in a course to runn him self owt of Breathe.
the 5 of
is moneth I Rxd one from yo
r
H. w
th
charge to deale w
th
e
states about
e acceptation of
e 1200 footemen, for 600 horse wh
r
in I
moved
em
e same daie, & since receaved such answer as I sent yo
r
H herein w
th
myne owne proposition.
t w
ch
I writ in my last of
e
enterprise of
Numigen
had that succes w
ch
I signified, onely now we
und
r
stand
t
e Townesmen since have [fished] for
Schenck,
& found him in
his [armo
r
] & since have cut him in quarters & set him on theyr gates
w
ch
extraordinary inhumanity doth so exasperate
e States, as they will
publish an Edict upon yt, that no quarters shalbe kept w
th
Neumighen.
Count Maurice
hath found
e meanes to convey 3 companies more into
Heusden.
ev
r
y souldier carieng w
th
him a quantity of pould
r
w
ch
is thought
in respect of
e want of
ey had w
th
in &
e danger of
e attempt a
great peice of
s
vice. My
L. Treasurers
good opinion & report of
my
s
vices w
ch
I know yo
r
H doth confirme, as occasyons ar p
r
sented
ar such incouragement
unto me as yf I knew by what meanes, I
would shew my self more worthy of yo
r
Honourable favoures. But
what I want in ability I hope to make up in diligence, w
ch
I do
assure yo
r
honor, to effect any good, must be more
en ordinary &
not [
en] many will imagine,
t
ar not heer in place to set
e
daily thwart
t
are offred, & theyr broken
ceeding
/ I am
glad to know by yo
r
H. that my often writing to my L. wilbe
well accepted, yt is
e best point of
e
s
vice w
ch
I would willingly
shew to his L. w
ch
I have purposely forborne leste writing to yo
r
H, w
ch
yf there were any matter was also written to my L. I might
seeme to be more troublesome then my buisines did require./
